name: Arsenio Jazmin
description: Personal Best: 400 – 48.49 (1962).

name: Emily Clark
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (0–3–1 2015 Malmö silver; 2016 Kamloops silver; 2017 Plymouth silver; 2019 Espoo bronze)

name: Imre Szalay
description: Imre Szalay started wrestling at MTE in 1919. At first, he competed in middleweight, but due to strong competition, he eventually chose to campaign at light-heavyweight. He achieved his most significant successes in this weight class where he became the multiple champion of Hungary. He was in great shape in 1924, but due to his working-class background and political views, he was not selected to Olympic team. He played an active role in the communist movement from a young age. He was arrested for participating in a workers’ demonstration in 1925 and was banned from competing abroad for years. Despite this situation, he was chosen for the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics and finished in fifth place. He passed away at a relatively young age due to persecution and inhumane working conditions during World War II. In his memory, a wrestling competition was held from 1949.

name: Naftali Bon
description: Naftali Bon ran the 400 metres at the 1972 München Olympics. He also helped Kenya win a silver medal in the 4x400 relay. Bon also ran the 800 metres with his best time coming in the United States at Echo Summitt, California in September 1969. He ran the 800 at the 1970 Commonwealth Games although he did not advance past round one. Little is known of his life outside athletics. Personal Best: 400 – 46.21 (1968).

name: Vivi Markussen
description: Personal Best: 100 – 11.6 (1959).

name: Calixto Malcom
description: Calixto Malcom played basketball for Panama at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics. He later became much better known in Panama as a lawyer and judge. Malcolm was a presiding magistrate on the Maritime Appeals Court. His outstanding career in public service was accompanied by his dedication to teaching, which was remembered and appreciated by his alumni.

name: Chalermpol Noohlong
description: Chalermpol Noohlong was a member of the 4×400 m team who made 3:05.79 for a 5th place at the Asian Championship 2000, and thereby qualified for the Olympics, his latest appearance internationally. Personal Best: 400 – 47.58 (2001).

name: Mike Foy
description: Michial Foy had the following finishes at major championships – 1989 World Championship: 90.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd); 1994 World Championship: 90.0 kg. Greco-Roman (5th); 1995 Pan-American Games: 90.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–1–0 1995 Mar del Plata WRE silver: Greco-Roman light-heavyweight -90 kg)

name: Karl Kowanz
description: Defender Karl Kowanz was a member of the Austrian football team at the 1948 London Olympics. They lost their first-round match 3-0 to the eventual gold medallists Sweden. In total, Kowanz won 17 international caps. Domestically, Kowanz played with SK Admira Wien (Vienna) (until 1950), FK Austria Wien (Vienna) (1950-58), and Wiener (Vienna) AC (1958-61). He helped Austria Wien win the Austrian Championship in 1950 and 1953 and Wiener AC win the Austrian Cup in 1959. Kowanz turned to coaching after his active career and worked with Grazer AK, Sturm Graz, Badener AC, AS Admira Neustadt Wien (Vienna), and 1. Wiener (Vienna) Neustädter AC. His children Karl and Brigitte became well-known artists in Austria.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 1960 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (1 App. - 0 goals - 90 min. played: HUN 0:4 (h))

name: Slavko Janjušević
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 1963 Napoli ROW silver: eights)

name: Kissya Costa
special_notes: Listed in Doping Irregularities at the Olympics (2012 London – Single sculls (18). Erythropoietin (EPO).)

name: Rinus Terlouw
description: Via CVV Zwervers (Capelle aan den IJssel) Terlouw started playing for DCV (Krimpen aan den IJssel). Despite being a second division team, his playing earned him a spot in the national team, where he would play 34 matches, including 5 as a captain. Rinus Terlouw played for Sparta from 1949, with whom he reached the play-off pool for the title in 1956 (placing fourth and last). Terlouw, known as a rock-solid defender, played with the team until 1958, after which he became a trainer for DCV. In 1965, he decided to break with his football past, throwing out all his scrapbooks, awards, etc. to return to the reformed church, where he served as a deacon between 1975 and 1981. He passed away in 1992, having suffered from Alzheimer’s disease for several years.

name: Xoxó
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 1991 La Habana ROW bronze: coxed pairs)

name: Fritz Köppen
description: East German long jumper Fritz Köppen did not qualify for the final at the 1960 Roma Olympic Games. The versatile track and field athlete was East German Champion in the long jump in 1959 and the decathlon in 1957. Köppen studied to be a mechanic tool engineer. Personal Best: LJ – 7.69 (1960).

name: Mariusz Podkościelny
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (0–0–2 1989 Bonn SWM bronze: 400 m freestyle and 1500 m freestyle)

name: Nana Miyagi

name: Dawn Harper
description: In the 100m hurdle final at the 2008 Olympic Games, Harper, in her first Olympics, was lined up against countrywoman LoLo Jones, whose race it was to lose. Harper ran a consistent and clean race and was in contention enough to capture the gold medal in a personal best time of 12.54 seconds when Jones clipped hurdle nine, and Australia’s Sally Pearson couldn’t maintain her hurdle five lead. In the 100m hurdle final four years later in London in 2012, Harper was making gains on Pearson and just ran out of real estate, leaving her unable to defend her 2008 Olympic title, but she was delighted in winning silver and setting a personal best of 12.37 seconds, tying the best ever USA performance at the Olympic Games. Harper went to the 2009 World Championships in Berlin and while she ran a personal best in the semi-finals (12.48), she clipped hurdle two in the final finishing seventh. After a season-ending knee injury in 2010 and with only four months of training, Harper went to the 2011 World Championships in Daegu and won the bronze medal in a personal best time (12.47). She finished a disappointing fourth at the 2013 World Championships in Moscow but ended her season on a high note beating the exact same field (excluding the champion) as in Moscow Worlds, at the Diamond League Final in Belgium, and winning her second Diamond League title. Since graduating from the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) in 2006 with a degree in psychology, Harper trained under Bobby Kersee. A 2002 graduate of East St. Louis High School in Illinois, USA, she won six state titles (three each in the 100m and 300m hurdles). After winning Olympic gold in 2008, the Governor of Illinois declared 6 October as Dawn Harper Day honouring her for her success and humble beginnings being from East St. Louis, the same hometown as the great Olympic champion Jackie Joyner-Kersee. After winning her silver medal in 2012, Harper was named an Ambassador for the United Way for Greater St. Louis Education Express where she is involved in promoting the value and importance of education in the region. In preparation for her wedding to Alonzo Nelson in 2013, Harper appeared on the episode called “Race to the Alter” on The Learning Channel’s popular TV show “Say Yes to the Dress” where brides are assisted by bridal consultants in picking out their wedding dress. She was previously married to former USA 400m runner Craig Everhart (PB 44.89). Personal Best: 100H – 12.37 (2012)
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Championships (0–1–1 2011 Daegu bronze: 100 m hurdles; 2017 London silver: 100 m hurdles (competed as Dawn Harper-Nelson))

name: Yavuz Selekman
description: Yavuz Selekman won wrestling bronze medals at consecutive World Championships, in 1961 and 1962, in the welterweight, Greco-Roman event. In 1963, he was the winner of this division at the Mediterranean Games. He was then selected to represent Turkey at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics, but as a middleweight, where he was eliminated in round four. He retired from active competition after the Games and entered the film and television industry in 1965, amassing dozens of credits over the next four decades. He was still working on a television show when he fell ill in late 2003 and died after three months of treatment.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Acted in Movies (Numerous films from the 1960s until his death) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–0–0 1963 Napoli WRE gold: Greco-Roman welterweight -78 kg)

name: Tootje Selbach
special_notes: Sister of Toetie Selbach

name: Hilary Gehman
description: Hilary Gehman rowed quad sculls for the United States at the 2000 and 2004 Olympic Games. She rowed in college at Colby College, graduating with a degree in sociology and classical civilization. She was a six-time member of the US National Team. Even while competing Gehman was coaching rowing. She was head coach at Lewis & Clark College from 1996-98 and then coached at Georgetown University (2000-03) and Cornell University (2004-14). In 2016 she became the events manager and director of the Mercer Rowing Programs for the Princeton National Rowing Association. Internationally Gehman coached the US Rowing women’s freshman camp in 2008, 2009, and 2011. She was coach of the U-23 women’s quad at the 2010 and 2018 World Championships, the men’s four at the 2015 Pan American Games, and she was the 2020 USA Olympic Team women’s quad sculls rowing coach.

name: Edwin Jacob
description: In 1924, Edwin Jacob won a silver medal in the 8-metre class at the Paris Olympics when he was one of the five-man crew aboard Emily. He enjoyed many of his successes between 1923-29, however, aboard the East Coast One Design (ECOD), Joyce, which he co-owned with Kenneth Elphinstone and R. Proctor. From 1930, Jacob raced the under-8 ton class Bubbles II, and they enjoyed success in his home town at that year’s Burnham Week.

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–1 1978 Bangkok SWM bronze: 4×100 m freestyle relay)

name: Roberto Pistarini
special_notes: Son of Pascual Pistarini

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–2 1982 Brisbane ATH bronze: 110 m hurdles; 1986 Edinburgh ATH bronze: 110 m hurdles)

name: Norbert Kindlmann
description: Norbert Kindlmann was a member of the West German eights at the 1972 München Olympics that finished a disappointing fifth. He later became a youth coach at his home club Rüsselsheimer RK 08. Kindlmann won two West German national titles. By profession he became a construction engineer, and was employed by the Wiesbaden Council.

name: Héctor Begeo
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–0–1 1982 New Delhi ATH bronze: 3000 m steeplechase)

name: Bernhard Cuiper
description: The German team did not play any significant role in the 1936 Berlin Olympics when basketball was included in the program for the first time. They lost their first round match to Switzerland (25-18) but still qualified for round two after receiving a bye in the Repêchage, but were then beaten heavily, 58-16 by Italy. Given another chance in the round two Repêchage, their campaign ended with a 20-9 defeat by Czechoslovakia. Bernhard Cuiper was a professional soldier and played nationally for Heeressportschule Wünsdorf, winning the first unofficial German Championship with them in 1938.

name: Wen Lirong

name: Jean Debuf
description: Jean Debuf had the following podium finishes at major championships: 3rd in the 1956 Olympics Middle-Heavyweight class (425.0 kg); 2nd in the 1949 World Championships Light-Heavyweight class (382.5 kg); 2nd in the 1951 World Championships Light-Heavyweight class (392.5 kg); 3rd in the 1954 World Championships Light-Heavyweight class (405.0 kg); 2nd in the 1948 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class; 1st in the 1949 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class (382.5 kg); 1st in the 1951 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class (392.5 kg); 3rd in the 1952 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class; 2nd in the 1954 European Championships Light-Heavyweight class (405.0 kg); 2nd in the 1955 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (410.0 kg); 1st in the 1956 European Championships Middle-Heavyweight class (427.5 kg).

name: Kerstin Spittler
description: East German rower Kerstin Spittler partnered Katrin Schröder in the coxless pairs at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, and finished fourth. In 1985, she won both the nationals with the coxed fours, and the world title, and the following year won the silver medal. In 1986 and 1988, Spittler won national golds with the eights, and at the 1987 Worlds, they finished fourth. In 1988, Spittler also won the coxless pairs national title with Martina Schröter.

name: Wolfgang Brinkmann
description: Equestrian Wolfgang Brinkmann was on the West German show jumping team that won the gold medal at the 1988 Seoul Olympics. In the individual event, he was eliminated in the first round. Together with his brother Klaus, Wolfgang ran the textile company Bugatti Holding Brinkmann GmbH & Co. KG, one of the largest German men’s fashion manufacturers, founded by their father Friedrich Wilhelm Brinkmann. After the death of his father in 1994 Wolfgang ran a breeding stable. The entrepreneur built up equestrian accessories companies Pikeur and Eskadron, became a breeder of high-class show jumping horses, and trained his two sons Torsten and Markus.

special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (0–1–1 2014 Incheon HOC bronze; 2018 Jakarta/Palembang HOC silver)

name: Pietro Freschi
description: Pietro Freschi was an Italian rower who was a member of the Vittorino da Feltre club. With Umberto Bonadé, Paolo Gennari, and the stroke Cesare Rossi, Freschi contributed to one of the best Italian crews between the World Wars. The crew of the coxless four, nicknamed “I gazzosini”, perhaps from the fact that the boat was not inaugurated with the classic sparkling wine but with a more modest bottle of soda, came together in 1927 and was composed of three firemen and a municipal clerk. Freschi and his crew won the 1928 national title and repeated through 1931. Internationally their brightest moment was at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics where, despite Bonadè’s health issues (three surgeries for a glandular abscess), they managed to win bronze. Upon returning to Piacenza, the quartet was carried on the fans’ shoulders from the railway station to the main square. In the following years the crew won the 1929 European title in Bydgoszcz and defended in 1930 in Liège (beating Switzerland and Belgium). They stayed together through 1931 and then retired. Freschi also won the Gold Cup, which was awarded to those who won the Lucerne regattas for three consecutive years.

name: Dale Thomas
description: Dale Thomas won nine US titles in collegiate, freestyle, and Greco-Roman wrestling. But he later became better known as a wrestling coach. He coached Oregon State from 1957 until his retirement in 1990, helping them win 22 Pac Eight titles. He was inducted into the US Wrestling Hall of Fame in 1990. He also was a wrestling official at the 1960 and 1964 Olympics and several World Championships. Thomas had the following finishes at major championships – 1954 World Championship: 87.0 kg. Freestyle (6th).

name: Jouko Törmänen
description: Jouko Törmänen made his international début at the 1974 World Championships, where he was fifth on the large hill. At the 1976 Winter Olympics Törmänen was tenth on the large hill and 14th on the normal hill. At the 1978 World Championships, Törmänen won his first international championship medal, a silver in the team event, while placing sixth on the large hill and 15th on the normal hill. The high point of Törmänen’s career was at the 1980 Olympic Winter Games, where he won a gold on the large hill and was eighth on the normal hill. Törmänen made his last international appearance at the 1982 World Championships, placing 22nd on the large hill. Domestically Törmänen won four Finnish titles, in 1976-77 and 1979-80, all on the normal hill. By profession Törmänen was an engineer. He also became a board member of the Finnish Skiing Federation in 1988, and served as vice-president of the Finnish Skiing Federation from 1993-2002. In 1992 he was named chairman of the Ski Jumping and Nordic Combined Committee of the Finnish Skiing Federation and in 2004 was named chairman of the Ski Jumping Committee of the Fédération Internationale de Ski (FIS).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were on the Podium at the Four Hills Tournament (1977/78 Innsbruck third) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Nordic Ski Championships (1–0–0 1978 Lahti SJP silver: team (unoffical); 1980 Lake Placid (Olympics) SJP gold: large hill)

name: Harold Hammack
description: Harold Hammack was a running back who subbed in for Gene Clark on the West Team. Hammack played football at Southern Cal. He later served as a lieutenant in the US Navy during World War II.

name: Rainer Schüttler
description: German tennis player Rainer Schüttler started his Olympic career at the 2000 Sydney Olympics losing his second-round match to the Brazilian #2 seed Guga Kuerten. Schïuttler then won the silver medal at the 2004 Athina Olympics in the men’s doubles with Nicolas Kiefer, losing in five sets to the Chilean pair of Fernando Gónzalez and Nicolas Massú. Schüttler and Kiefer were awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. In the single’s tournament he lost his first-round match, and in 2008 at Beijing again his second-round match. At Beijing Schüttler also lost his first-round match in the doubles with Kiefer. Schüttler reached his highest position with #5 in the world rankings in 2004. In 2003, he reached the final at the Australian Open losing to André Agassi. In 2008, Schüttler was a semi-finalist at the Wimbledon Tournament. In total, he won four ATP tournaments. From 1999-2009 he played for the German Davis Cup team. Schüttler later turned to coaching and notably coached Angelique Kerber from 2018-19, among others. He became chief coach of the German Billy-Jean-King-Team in 2019, and also organized several ATP tournaments in Germany. He later resided in Switzerland near Zürichsee with his wife and two boys.

name: John Winnett
description: John Winnett was born in Los Angeles but spent much of his youth in Europe where he began riding dressage and jumping. He was 1945 French Junior National Champion in dressage. Moving back to the United States Winnett worked as a stockbroker, but retired in 1970 to devote himself to equestrian sport and training dressage horses. He and his wife settled in Wellington, Florida where they taught dressage and jumping and trained horses. Winnett competed at the 1975 Pan American Games, winning a silver medal in individual dressage and a gold in team dressage. Winnett wrote the book Dressage as Art in Competition, first published in 1993.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–1–0 1975 Ciudad de México EQU gold: dressage team, silver: dressage individual)

name: Jón Karl Sigurðsson
special_notes: Father of Sigurður Jónsson

name: Sandra Whyte
description: Sandra Whyte played center for Harvard University while in college, where she schored 85 goals, with 55 assists. She was All-Ivy League first team in 1989, 1991, and 1992, was the MVP of the Beanpot Tournament in 1992, and was Ivy League Player of the Year in 1991 and 1992, as well as ECAC Player of the Year in 1991. Whyte played for the US team in 1997-98, competing at the 1997 World Championships. She later became a hockey coach at Reading High School in Massachusetts.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (0–3–0 1992 Tampere silver; 1994 Lake Placid silver; 1997 Kitchener silver)

name: Lyudmila Panchuk
description: Lyudmila Panchuk was on the Soviet national team from 1974-82. She won an Olympic gold in 1976, a World Championship in 1982, and won silver at the 1975 Worlds. Panchuk missed the 1980 Olympics due to pregnancy. At the club level, she played her whole career with Spartak Kyiv, winning Soviet titles in 1974-77 and 1982-83, and the EHF Champions League in 1975, 1977 and 1983. Panchuk finished her competitive career after the 1983 season due to an Achilles tendon rupture.

name: Masatoshi Kobayashi
special_notes: Husband of Yuko Otaka Father of Yumie Kobayashi

name: Esther Jones
description: Esther Jones was a sprinter at LSU who helped the Lady Tigers to win six NCAA team titles (four outdoor, two indoors) during her career. She was a 10-time Southeastern Conference champion. Jones was NCAA Champion at 100 and 200 metres in 1990, runner-up at 100 metres in 1989 and 1991 and 200 metres in 1991, and finished third in 1988 in the 100. Internationally Jones won gold medals in the 4x100 relay at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics and the 1989 World University Games. She was inducted into the LSU Athletic Hall of Fame in 2007. Jones’ brother, Mark, played 10 games for the Orlando Magic in the NBA in the 2004/05 season. Her nephew, Trey McKinney, also played in the NBA, making his début in 2018 with the Indiana Pacers. Personal Bests: 100 – 11.11 (1991), 11.09A (1994), 10.99w (1991); 200 – 22.47 (1992).

name: Sule Ladipo
description: Sule Ladipo was a Nigerian tennis player who played for his country in the Davis Cup from 1992 to 2000. He turned professional in 1993 and reached his highest singles ranking of 245 in the world in April 1996. Later the same year he represented Nigeria at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics but lost his first round match to Australia’s Jason Stoltenberg.

name: Jürgen Wohlers
description: Small forward Jürgen Wohlers was on the West German basketball team at the 1972 München Olympics. The team lost both the classification match for places 9-12 against Australia by only one point (70-69), and also lost the 11th place match by one point against Spain (84-83). Wohlers earned 174 international caps, which was a national record at the time. Domestically, he played with MTV Wolfenbüttel (1966-69 and after 1970) and USC München (1969-70). Wohlers helped Wolfenbüttel win the West German Cup in 1972. His children Viktoria and Moritz also became basketball players.

name: Tomas Gadeikis
description: Tomas Gadeikis had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 1st 2009 C2 200 m (with Raimundas Labuckas), 1st 2010 C2 200 m (with Raimundas Labuckas), 1st 2011 C2 200 m (with Raimundas Labuckas), 3rd 2006 C2 200 m (with Raimundas Labuckas), 3rd 2007 C2 200 m (with Raimundas Labuckas).

name: Ned Gourdin
description: With the possible exception of Sol Butler, Ned Gourdin of Harvard was the first of the great black long jumpers (he was also part Seminole Native American). On 23 July 1921, at the Harvard-Yale vs. Oxford/Cambridge meet, he set a world record of 25-3 (7.69), defeating the British first string, Harold Abrahams, by the shattering margin of almost three feet. This was the first legal long jump over 25 feet. Gourdin was also an outstanding sprinter and at the same meet defeated Abrahams, the future Olympic champion of “Chariots of Fire” fame, in the 100y. Gourdin won the AAU long jump in 1921, the pentathlon in 1921-22, and the IC4A long jump in 1921. Gourdin, a lawyer, was admitted to the Massachusetts bar in 1925 and the Federal bar in 1931. He became a U.S. attorney in 1936 and in 1958 became the first black to become a member of the Massachusetts Supreme Court. Personal Bests: LJ – 7.69 (1921).

name: Karen Gardiner-Kah
description: Competed in 1988 Olympic Short-Track Speedskating demonstration events.

name: Bakary Jarjue
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.3 (1979).

name: Johannes Viljoen
description: Johannes Viljoen had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1930 British Empire Games High Jump, 3rd in the 1930 British Empire Games Long Jump. In the 1930 British Empire Games 120 yards Hurdles he finished fourth but in the 1930 British Empire Games 220 yards as well as in the 1930 British Empire Games 440 yards Hurdles he was eliminated in the heats. He also competed in the final of the 1934 British Empire Games 120 yards Hurdles but did not finish the race. Personal Bests: 100 – unknown; 110H – 14.6y (1933); LJ – 7.50 (1929); TJ – unknown; Dec – unknown.

name: Hubert Ramsey
description: One of England’s most talented players, Hubert Ramsey was regarded as the best cover point in England before World War I. He could also play as defence wing, and went on to win representative honours for London, Essex, the South, England and Great Britain. He played his club lacrosse with Woodford and was, in 1903, elected vice-captain of the Essex County Lacrosse Club. Ramsey spent most of his working life on the floor of the London Stock Exchange.

name: Ozren Bonačić
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Water Polo Championships (0–0–3 1966 Utrecht bronze; 1970 Barcelona bronze; 1974 Wien bronze) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (1–1–0 1967 Tunis WAP gold; 1975 Al-Jaza'ir WAP silver)

name: Axel Birnbaum
description: Axel Birnbaum was Austrian champion in individual épée (1991) and in team épée (1990).
special_notes: Son of Udo Birnbaum

name: Zdeněk Pěkný
special_notes: Cousin of Filip Vejdělek

name: Hans Andersson-Tvilling
description: Along with his twin brother Stig, Hans Andersson-Tvilling took up ice hockey in 1947. Like his brother, he played his entire career from 1947-58 with Djurgårdens IF and won four Swedish titles with them (1950, 1954, 1955, 1958). Internationally, Andersson-Tvilling earned 87 caps with the Swedish national team. He won an Olympic bronze in 1952, was a World Champion in 1953, won silver at the 1951 World Championships and bronze at the 1954 World Championships. He was also a European Champion from 1951-53, while taking silver at the 1954 European Championships and bronze at the 1955 European Championships. Andersson-Tvilling was also an accomplished football player, earning four caps with the Swedish national team. He was awarded the Stora Grabbars Märke (Big Boys’ Badge) #44 in ice hockey, a Swedish sports honorary award created in 1928 by Bo Ekelund. After finishing his sporting career, Andersson-Tvilling coached for a long time with Tranebergs IF.
special_notes: Twin brother of Stig Andersson-Tvilling Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (3–1–1 1951 Paris gold; 1952 Oslo (Olympics) gold; 1953 Zürich and Basel gold; 1955 Krefeld, Dortmund, and Köln bronze; 1956 Cortina d’Ampezzo (Olympics) silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–1–1 1951 Paris silver; 1952 Oslo (Olympics) bronze; 1953 Zürich and Basel gold)

name: Yosuke Eto
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–1–1 1962 Villars SJP silver, NCB bronze)

name: Harry Reeves
description: Harry Reeves shot free pistol for the United States at the 1952 Olympics. Reeves was a six-time national champion in pistol shooting. He started shooting in 1934 while serving in the US Marine Corps, winning the Navy Championship soon after he started competing. Reeves left the Marines in 1937 and joined the Detroit Police Force, but re-upped with the Marines in 1941 to serve in World War II. He left active duty in 1946 and joined the Marine Reserves, while returning to the Detroit police, retiring as a police inspector in 1964. In his honor the National Rifle Association (NRA) Police Semi-Automatic Service Pistol Match at the NRA National Police Shooting Championships receives the Harry Reeves Memorial Trophy.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (4–4–2 1949 Buenos Aires gold: 25 m center fire pistol team, silver: 50 m free pistol and 25 m rapid-fire pistol, bronze: 50 m free pistol team and 25 m rapid-fire pistol team; 1952 Oslo gold: 25 m center fire pistol, 25 m center fire pistol team, and 25 m rapid-fire pistol team; 1954 Caracas silver: 25 m center fire pistol team and 50 m free pistol team)

name: Babe Slater
description: Babe Slater came from northern California and went to school at “Cal Aggie,” now known as the University of California at Davis. While in school he played mostly basketball, but played enough rugby to make two Olympic teams. After graduating from Cal Aggie, he became a rancher in the Sacramento Delta, interrupted only by his infantry service in Europe during the 2nd World War. He returned to his hometown of Clarksburg and farmed there the rest of his life.
special_notes: Brother of Norm Slater

name: Ahmed Saïd
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 1975 Al-Jaza'ir BOX silver: light-flyweight -48 kg)

name: Alex Ireland
description: Alex Ireland was the 1921 British Amateur Champion. He fought as a professional from 1922-30, winning 33 fights, losing 10, and drawing 3, as a welterweight and middleweight. He made three failed attempts to win the Scottish Area title as a welterweight, all against “Hamilton” Johnny Brown. In 1928 he took the European Middleweight title, by defeating Tommy Milligan in Edinburgh, winning at the same time the Commonwealth and British Middleweight titles. Six months later Ireland defended the Commonwealth and British titles against Welshman Frank Moody. Another half-year later, in May 1929, he was knocked out by Len Harvey from Cornwall, and after losing another title bout for the Scottish Championship against Harvey, Ireland retired from boxing.

name: Marylise Lévesque
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (0–0–1 2007 Rio de Janeiro JUD bronze: half-heavyweight -78 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 2007 Bangkok JUD bronze: half-heavyweight -78 kg)

name: Hans Luber
description: German diver Hans Luber was European Champion on platform in 1926 and 1927. Between 1910 and 1927 he won 13 German Championships. In 1912 and 1913 Luber also won the Austrian Championships. At the 1912 Stockholm Olympics Luber was eliminated in the first round of the platform and the plain high diving event, but he took silver on springboard behind his teammate Paul Günther, but ahead of Kurt Behrens and Albert Zürner, underlining the German dominance in this event. By profession, Luber became a teacher at the Deutsche Hochschule für Leibeserziehungen (German High School for Gymnastic Exercises) in Leipzig, and also a sports teacher for the Berlin Electricity Company. In 1914 he wrote the textbook Der Schwimmsport.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Aquatics Championships (2–0–0 1926 Budapest DIV gold: platform; 1927 Bologna DIV gold: platform)

name: Pierre Durand
description: At the Olympics, Pierre Durand competed in both eventing and show jumping, over a period of 12 years. Durand was 1962 World Military Champion in eventing. Durand was a career military officer, retiring as a General, after which he became director of the French National Riding School from 1984-88. There is no relation to Pierre Durand who competed at two Olympic Games, winning a gold medal in individual jumping at the 1988 Seoul Olympics.

name: Erich Hotopf
description: German sports shooter Erich Hotopf participated in the small-bore rifle event over 50 metres at the 1936 Berlin Olympics and finished 23rd. At the 1950 World Championships held in Olso he won a bronze medal as member of the German free rifle prone team. By profession, Hotopf was a policeman. In 1964 he won his only German national title.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–0–1 1952 Oslo bronze: 50+100 m free rifle prone team (competed for West Germany))

name: Leigh Barczewski
description: Leigh Barczewski was a track sprinter who placed fourth at the 1973 World Junior Championships in the match sprint. He was also fourth at the US Championships in 1974 but improved in 1976 to win the US Olympic Trials and compete in Montréal. He settled in the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania, where he worked in various roles at the Trexlertown Velodrome, becoming technical director of the track after he retired from competition in 1980. His son Ben Barczewski won a silver medal in the sprint event at the 2007 Pan American Games.

name: Ivano Camozzi
special_notes: Husband of Michela Figini

name: Lisette Sevens
description: World Champion with the Dutch Team in 1974, 1978, 1979 and 1983. European Champion 1984.

name: Giacomo Mosele
description: Giacomo Mosele came from a large family that participated in a wide variety of sports, and several of his siblings won Italian championships in track athletics. Giacomo started off as a distance runner as well, but after World War II he took an interest in skiing. He soon specialized in cross-country skiing and came in second, behind Federico De Florian, in the 18 kilometer event at the national championships in 1952. This qualified him to represent his country at that year’s Oslo Olympics, where he placed 34th in a field of 80 entrants. His only other major domestic podium finish came in 1954, when he was again second behind De Florian, this time in the 50 kilometer competition. After retirement, he ran the Hotel Da Barba (“Beard” – Mosele’s nickname as an athlete) in his native Asiago, as well as a ski school.

name: Martin Strege
description: Policeman Martin Strege was a German steeplechase- and marathon-runner who finished tenth in the 3,000 metres steeplechase at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. In 1990, 1994, and 1998 he became European police steeplechase champion, and was the German champion in 1994 and 1995. He also participated in several city marathons. Personal Best: 3000S – 8:18.57 (1995).

name: Riccardo Bertazzolo
description: Riccardo Bertazzolo was an Italian boxer. As an amateur he competed at the 1924 Paris Olympics and was beaten in the quarter-finals of the heavyweight division by the Norwegian Otto Von Porat, the eventual gold medalist. Bertazzolo suffered a defeat in his pro début by disqualification but then recorded victories in 16 of his next 17 fights which included wins over the future European champion Pierre Charles as well as a number of other good fighters. This earned him a European title fight against Britain’s Phil Scott at the Royal Albert Hall in London in January 1927 where the Italian was once again disqualified. In his next fight Bertazzolo ousted Erminio Spalla from his position of Italian champion. Unfortunately, after a draw with George Cook and a defeat in Denmark against Knute Hansen, Bertazzolo was banned by the F.P.I. (the Italian Boxing Federation) for his behaviour during quarrels with his manager and stripped him of his championship. In 1929 Bertazzolo left for America where he began his stay with a trio of victories but then lost against several prominent contenders like Johnny Risko, Ted Sandwina and Charley Retzlaff . He also fought future world champion Primo Carnera in a bout contested between the two best Italian heavyweights of the time in Atlantic City. Bertazzolo was a colourful figure who would take his pet lion for walks around the streets of Milano and had a tattoo of a woman on his chest so, he claimed, his more chivalrous opponents would avoid so as not to be seen striking a woman.

name: Jan Kozák

name: Peter Lunn
description: Peter Lunn was the son of the travel agent, skiing journalist, and founder of the Alpine and Kandahar Ski Clubs, Arnold Lunn. Not surprisingly, Lunn Jr. started skiing at the age of two, and as a youngster took part in races at Mürren, often beating men much older than him. He won the slalom and combined at the Kandahar Club Under-18 Junior Championships at the age of 11. Lunn was educated at Eton and later worked for the Standard Motor Company before joining the family travel agency that was started by his grandfather Sir Henry Lunn at the end of the 19th century. They were pioneers of British winter skiing tourism to the Alps. Peter was a member of the British ski team from 1931-37 and, at the age of 21, was captain of the British team at the Garmisch-Partenkirchen Olympics in 1936. Lunn joined the Royal Artillery in 1940 and was posted to Malta and then co-opted into MI5, from where he was transferred to the Special Intelligent Service (SIS), who he went on to serve for over 40 years, seeing service in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, England and Beirut. He retired in 1972, but was re-employed by the SIS as a lecturer, researcher and counsellor. He finally retired in 1986 after an horrific car accident the previous year. Despite being told he would probably never walk again, Lunn became president of the Kandahar Club, started skiing again, and continued skiing into his 90s. He wrote several skiing manuals, and also a thriller. Lunn was awarded the OBE in 1951 and the CMG (Commander of the Order of St. Michael and St. George) in 1957.

name: Liz Barnes
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Athletics Indoor Championships (0–0–1 1980 Sindelfingen bronze: 800 m)

name: Nadine Capellmann
description: Nadine Capellmann was a German dressage rider who won the team gold medal at the 2000 Sydney and 2008 Beijing Olympics on her horses Farbenfroh and Elvis VA. Individually, she finished an unfortunate fourth in 2000, and 16th in 2008. Capellmann’s greatest year came in 2002, when she won the World Championships both individually, and with the German team. She added two more team gold medals in 1998 and 2006. At the Europeans, she won three team golds in 1997, 1999, and 2001, and a silver in 2007. Individually, she won the bronze medal in 2001. In 1999 and 2001-02, Capellmann won the national title. She was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf, Germany’s highest sports award. By profession, she became a graduated business manager. Her sister Grit also was a dressage rider, and her father Kurt was the long-time president of Aachen-Laurensberger Rennverein, organising the annual CHIO tournament at Aachen.

name: Aleksandr Anufriyev
description: Aleksandr Anufriyev was born in an extreme northern village of Russia in a Komi-Izhemtsy family, a northernmost sub-group of the Komi people, an ethnic group whose homeland is in the extreme northeastern part of Russia, mostly north of Arctic Circle. Anufriyev and his family made their living as fishermen until 1944 when he was mobilized to the Soviet Army and sent to the Karelian Front. After being wounded, Anufriyev took up athletics to overcome the effects of his injury. After demobilization in 1950, Anufriyev decided not to return to his homeland and started to work as a mechanic with Gorky Automobile Plant GAZ. Anufriyev also continued his athletics career and the apex of his career was 1952, when he won his only two Soviet titles (5K, 10K) and was selected for the 1952 Soviet Olympic team. At the Olympic Games, Anufriyev won a surprising bronze medal behind legendary Emil Zátopek and Alain Mimoun in the 10,000 and then finished a distant 10th in the 5,000 final four days later. After his great 1952 season, Anufriyev continued competing, but was overshadowed by Volodymyr Kuts and Pyotr Bolotnikov in domestic races, winning only four bronzes in the next four years at the Soviet Championships, before retiring in 1956 after he was not selected for the 1956 Soviet Olympic team. He then worked at the Zaporizhstal steel mill in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine until he decided to return to his homeland in 1963. Anufriyev settled in Naryan-Mar, the largest settlement in his native land and started to work in a local sawmill, but died rather young in September 1966 in a boating accident on river Pechora, about 10 km south of Naryan-Mar. Personal Bests: 5000 – 13:58.8 (1953); 10000 – 29:10.6 (1955).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Died in Motor Vehicle Accidents (Boat/Car/Motorcycle/Train) (Died in a boating accident on river Pechora, about 10 km from Narjan-Mara.)

name: Dieter Berkmann
description: Dieter Bergmann was a West German track cyclist who participated in the sprint at the 1972 München and 1976 Montréal Summer Olympics. He was eliminated in the second round repêchage in München and finished an unfortunate fourth in Montréal, losing the third place match against East German cyclist Hans-Jürgen Geschke. From 1972-74 and in 1976 Bermann won the West German national sprint title, and in 1975 also won a tandem title. After Montréal, Berkmann turned professional and won sprint silver medals in 1978 and 1979 at the World Professional championships. He also took part in 19 six-day races. Between 1982-84 he coached the West German track cycle team and then studied medicine, becoming an orthopedic surgeon and with his own practice. He was also the track doctor at the Six Days of Munich Six race from 1996-2009. In 2009 he lost in the election for the post of president of the German Cycling Union.

special_notes: Husband of Nicole Vaidišová

name: Stanislav Grigorov
description: Stanislav Grigorov had the following finishes at major championships – 1993 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Greco-Roman (5th).

name: Karl Frederick
description: Besides his competitive accomplishments at the 1920 Olympics, Karl Frederick captained the U.S. Olympic shooting team in 1948. He later became president of the National Rifle Association and a vice-president of the U.S. Revolver Association. Frederick attended Princeton, graduating in 1903, and then entered Harvard Law School, from which he earned an LL.B. in 1908. He made his career as a practicing lawyer in New York City for many years. He was also active in environmental causes, serving as chairman and president of the New York State Conservation Council and as a senior board member and Vice-Chairman of the executive committee of the American Forestry Association.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–0–1 1922 Milano bronze: 50 m free pistol team; 1923 Camp Perry gold: 50 m free pistol team)

name: Mohamed Naouar
description: Mohamed Naouar had the following finishes at major championships – 1996 African Championship: 100.0 kg. Greco-Roman (1st); 1997 African Championship: 97.0 kg. Greco-Roman (3rd); 1995 All-African Games: 100.0 kg. Greco-Roman (2nd).

name: Katie Sadleir
special_notes: Sister of Lynette Sadleir Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–0–1 1986 Edinburgh SYN bronze: solo)

name: Al Tripoli
description: Al Tripoli, from Yonkers, New York, first came into contact with boxing at age 16. However, his mother did not approve of him fighting, and Tripoli took to using the pseudonym Jack Williams to hide his activities. Under that name, he won the 1924 AAU Bantamweight title in Boston, and qualified for the Olympics in Paris. This forced Tripoli to tell his mother about his sport, but he finally left for France. He reached the final against Willie Smith, but lost it due to injuries on both hands. The silver medallists then went on to fight professionally. Although Tripoli was quite successful (60 wins out of 67), he never won any major titles.

name: Emilio Giovanoli
description: Emilio Giovanoli was an Italian middle distance runner of the early 20th century whose best event was the 5,000 metres. At the 1908 Italian Championships Giovanoli took second in the 5K behind Pericle Pagliani. This achievement qualified Giovanoli to participate at the 1908 London Olympics in the 3-mile team event. The following year he tried his hand at 1,500 metres. In Milano on 18 April a race was held, which in practice replaced the Italian Championship, which did not take place over this distance between 1907 and 1912. The race was won by the Olympian Massimo Cartasegna, just in front of Giovanoli, who ran 4:24.8.

name: Elvismar Rodríguez
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 2019 Lima JUD gold: middleweight -70 kg) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Central American and Caribbean Games (1–1–1 2014 Veracruz JUD bronze: middleweight -70 kg; 2018 Barranquilla JUD gold: middleweight -70 kg, silver: team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Youth Olympic Games (0–0–1 2014 Nanjing JUD bronze: half-heavyweight -78 kg)

name: Kenya Yasuda

name: Ernst Lehner
description: Ernst Lehner’s father was one of the founding members of what would become FC Augsburg and became an honorary member of the Southern German football association. Three of four brothers played football while the four sisters were all keen swimmers. Ernst joined Schwaben Augsburg when he was 8-years-old. At the age of 18 he was promoted to the club’s first team, for which he would play more than 500 matches. At the age of 21, the talented forward got his first international chance in a match against Switzerland in November 1933, when an injury sidelined the stater. Lehner took advantage of this opportunity and soon moved into the starting line-up. Of the 100 international matches played by Germany until the end of his international career, he appeared in 65, scoring 31 goals to become Germany’s record scorer at the time. Lehner’s specialty was corner kicks, quite often directly turning them into goals, even twice in a match against Estonia in August 1937. He took part in the 1934 and 1938 World Cups, playing six matches, was selected for the team of Western Europe in 1937 and was a member of the famous “Breslau 11.” In the 1930s he was considered the world’s best amateur player. In 1940 he went to join Blau-Weiß 90 Berlin, only to return to his home town Augsburg in 1942. After World War II he continued to play for Viktoria Aschaffenburg in the Southern Division of the “Oberliga” (Upper League). Later he coached Darmstadt 98, Viktoria Aschaffenburg and Hanau 93. He lived in Aschaffenburg because the local administration had offered him a job, unlike his home town of Augsburg. From 1947 until his retirement in 1978 he was the head of the city’s sports bureau. As a tribute the stadium of Schwaben Augsburg bears his name.

name: Gabrielle Smith
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Competed in the Boat Race (2022 Oxford (lost) - women's race)

name: Marthe Dupont
description: Marthe Dupont-Trasenster married Émile Dupont in October 1911 in Ougréé, Belgium. She competed at the 1920 and 1924 Olympics in tennis, her best finish coming in the 1920 women’s doubles, when she made the quarter-finals alongside Anne Chaudoir. Dupont-Trasenster was Belgian women’s singles champion in 1921 and 1930; won the Belgian doubles title in 1908, 1910, 1913, 1921, 1930, and 1933; and took the mixed doubles title in 1920, 1926, and 1931. Her older sister, Nelly, also played tennis at the national level in Belgium.
special_notes: Wife of Émile Dupont Cousin of Marguerite Chaudoir

name: John Sizmur
description: John Sizmur attended St. Dunstan’s College in Catford, London, and played most of his senior lacrosse for the Old Dunstonians. An England international, he was also a Middlesex county player, and represented The South in the prestigious annual match against The North. Sizmur was one of All-England’s six substitutes for the 1948 Olympics. In 1952 he moved to the Kenton club, and in 1953 was appointed treasurer of the South of England Lacrosse Association. Sizmur served with the RAF during World War II, and was promoted from flying officer to flight lieutenant in 1944, when he was involved in the Normandy landing, and was, that year, awarded the Air Force Cross (AFC).

name: Michał Butkiewicz
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1965 Budapest FEN bronze: épée team) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Fencing Championships (0–1–0 1970 Ankara silver: épée team)

name: Tom Treinen
description: Tom Treinen was an E-6 (first class petty officer) in the US Navy at the time of the 1976 Olympics. He had been All-Navy Rifle Champion in 1969 before switching to rapid fire pistol shooting. After retiring from the Navy, Treinen worked as a welder in the 1980s.

name: Yu Zhicheng
description: Personal Best: 110H – 13.68 (1990).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (2–0–0 1986 Seoul ATH gold: 110 m hurdles; 1990 Beijing ATH gold: 110 m hurdles)

name: Ernie Fearman
description: Ernest Fearman (for many years, believed to be Edward) enjoyed boxing success early in his career. In 1900, he reached the final of the bantamweight event at the Northampton Institute, and a year later was the winner of the Polytechnic Open lightweight title. The following year, 1902, Fearman reached the ABA lightweight final, losing to Highgate’s A. Warner, the defending champion. Although Fearman won little of note in the years leading up the 1908 London Olympics, he was still selected for the lightweight competition, but lost his opening bout to the eventual gold medallist, Fred Grace. Fearman was appointed Lynn BC vice-captain in 1909, and in 1913 became an ABA referee, officiating in many Championships. In 1932 he was made president of the Lynn club, in the year they moved to their new premises in Walworth Road, London. An electrician by trade, his brother William also boxed for the Lynn club.

name: Francisco Romualdo Gómez
description: Known as “Shon Ma”, Francisco Gómez played for Curaçao’s leading team in the 1950s, SUBT, Willemstad. A non-playing reserve at the 1952 Olympics, he went on to win the first of his 16 caps in the 1953 CCCF (Confederación Centroamericana y del Caribe de Fútbol) Championship, and was in the squad that won the bronze medal at the 1955 Pan American Games. He played in a FIFA World Cup qualifier against Costa Rica in 1957, and also played in that year’s CCCF Championship. He was in the Netherlands Antilles squad that won the silver medal at the 1959 Central American and Caribbean Games, and the following year he won his last cap, in a World Cup qualifier against Suriname.

Freestyle (4th); 1981 World Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (6th); 1983 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (3rd); 1984 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (4th); 1988 European Championship: 62.0 kg. Freestyle (12th).

name: Iwao Masuda
description: Iwao Masuda won the 400 metre title at the 1932 Japan Athletics Championships in 50 seconds flat, which earned him a place on the Japanese Olympic team, where he advanced only to round two. In the 4x400 metre relay, the Japanese team, including Masuda, placed fifth in the final. Personal Best: 400 – 50.0 (1932).

name: Daniel Gallery
description: Daniel Gallery attended the US Naval Academy in Annapolis, graduating at age 19, before wrestling in the 1920 Olympics. He came from a family with long roots in the US Navy. Gallery eventually rose to the rank of Rear Admiral in the Navy. He was an early Naval aviator who flew seaplanes, torpedo planes, and amphibians. In World War II Gallery commanded the Fleet Air Base in Reykjavik, Iceland, where he earned a Bronze Star for his actions against German submarines. In 1943 he became commander of the USS Guadalcanal, and led Task Group 22.3. With TG 22.3 he is best known for capturing and boarding a German U-boat. Task Group 22.3 was awarded the Presidential Unit Citation and Captain Gallery received the Distinguished Service Medal for capturing U-505. Gallery was put in command of the aircraft carrier USS Hancock near the end of the war. Gallery was later promoted to rear admiral and became Assistant to the Chief of Naval Operations. During the Korean War, he commanded Carrier Division Six. Gallery became embroiled in a dispute when plans were made to merge the Marines into the Army. He wrote a series of articles in The Saturday Evening Post that were so inflammatory that Gallery was fortunate to not be court-martialed for insubordination. The episode, however, prevented his promotion to Vice Admiral. His final command was in Puerto Rico with the 10th Naval District. While there he established the first Little Leagues on Puerto Rico and the first military steel band in 1957. The 10th Naval District Steel Band became the US Navy Steel Band, but called themselves Admiral Dan’s Pandemoniacs. Gallery was profiled out of the Navy in 1960 for medical reasons.

name: Brad Farrow
description: Brad Farrow won gold in the featherweight class (-63 kg) at the 1975 and 1979 Pan American Games and was the bronze medalist in the featherweight class (-65 kg) at the 1983 Pan American Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (2–0–1 1975 Ciudad de México JUD gold: featherweight -63 kg; 1979 San Juan JUD gold: featherweight -65 kg; 1983 Caracas JUD bronze: featherweight -65 kg)

name: Serena Eddy-Moulton
description: Serena Eddy-Moulton rowed the four for the USA at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics, with the crew finishing in fifth place. Eddy-Moulton was on the US national team from 1989-93, rowing at three World Championships, 1989, 1991, and 1993. She won a bronze medal in 1993 in the four. Eddy-Moulton attended Harvard, graduating in 1988. After college she worked for the Greater Boston Rehabilitation Services (GBRS) a nonprofit vocational agency providing career counseling and professional job placement assistance to people with physical and mental disabilities, where she was in charge of the agency’s marketing. She later became an associate director of career services at Boston College Law School.

name: Arun Sankosik
description: Personal Bests: 100 – unknown; 200 – unknown.

name: Wojciech Kurpiewski
description: Wojciech Kurpiewski competed at two Olympics, in 1988 and 1992, winning a silver medal in Barcelona in the K2-500 metres. At the World Championships, Kurpiewski won five medals. He won three silvers – in the 1987 and 1989 K4, and the 1993 K2-500; and two bronzes – in the 1986 K4 and the 1989 K2-500 metres. Kurpiewski later coached canoeing in Poland.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (1–1–1 1987 Zagreb CAN gold: K4 500 m, silver: K4 1000 m, bronze: K2 500 m) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–3–2 1986 Montréal bronze: K4 1000 m; 1987 Duisburg silver: K4 500 m; 1989 Plovdiv silver: K4 1000 m, bronze: K2 500 m; 1993 København silver: K2 500 m)

name: Mark Ruiz
description: Mark Ruiz was originally from Puerto Rico but competed in diving for the United States at the 2000 and 2004 Olympics. In 1999 he won all three individual events at the US Spring Nationals (platform, 3- and 1-metre springboards), the first diver since Greg Louganis in 1988 to accomplish that feat. At the Pan American Games Ruiz won gold in the 1999 springboard and bronze in the 2003 synchronized platform. At the 2000 Olympics Ruiz competed in three events – springboard, platform, and synchronized platform. Among US divers only he and David Pichler (2000) have competed in three of the four diving events through 2021 at the same Olympics. Ruiz later taught diving clinics in Florida. In 2010 his former team, Team Orlando Diving (TOD) merged with the YMCA of Central Florida and became YCF Diving and Ruiz was named head coach of the new club.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–1 1999 Winnipeg DIV gold: 3 m springboard; 2003 Santo Domingo DIV bronze: synchronized platform)

name: Rosemary Payne
description: Rosemary Payne had the following podium finishes at major championships: 1st in the 1970 British Commonwealth Games Discus Throw, 2nd in the 1974 British Commonwealth Games Discus Throw. She also finished tenth in the 1958 British Empire and Commonwealth Games discus throw, fourth in the 1966 British Empire and Commonwealth Games discus throw, and seventh in the 1974 British Commonwealth Games shot put. In the British (Empire and) Commonwealth Games she competed for Scotland. Personal Best: DT – 58.02 (1972).
special_notes: Wife (divorced) of Howard Payne Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (1–1–0 1970 Edinburgh ATH gold: discus throw (competed for Scotland); 1974 Christchurch ATH silver: discus throw (competed for Scotland))

name: Konstantinos Ditsios
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–0–1 1989 Duisburg ROW bronze: double sculls)

name: Stela Perin
description: Stela Perin was born in Arad. A member of the Romanian women’s Olympic gymnastics team in 1952, she was the most successful out of her eight teammates, scoring 71.85 individual points for a 25th place finish out of 134 competitors in individual all-around. She also placed in the top-30 in floor exercise and horse vault events. One of the top female gymnasts in her country of the 1950s, Perin won national titles at the Romanian National Championships in vault (1950, 1951, 1952, 1953) and floor exercise (1952, 1953 and 1954). She later became a gymnastics coach, and was awarded the title master of sports.

name: Maryna Proskurina
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–2–1 2003 Daegu GYM silver: vault; 2005 İzmir GYM bronze: vault; 2007 Bangkok GYM silver: team)

name: Aleksandr Chumakov
description: Aleksandr Chumakov was the son of the artist Aleksandr Chumakov, who was the main artist of the VDNKh (Vystavka Dostizheniy Narodnogo Khozyaystva), an amusement park and trade show in Moskva. The son started sailing in the later 1930s. During World War II, he led a group of young people in Moskva who put out fire-bombs at night and, during the day. dug anti-tank ditches. After the war, he returned to sailing and competed in a new yacht class “Olympic“, in which he twice won the USSR Championship, in 1946 and 1948. He competed in the Star Class at the 1952 Olympics alongside Konstantin Melgunov, aboard Hurricane. In 1956 Chumakov was a crew member in the Sharpie Class for Boris Ilyin, aboard Kon-Tiki. During one of the races, the boat turned over and Chumakov broke a rib, but still continued to compete, their boat eventually placing seventh. In the early 1960s, Chumakov switched to coaching, notably leading Viktor Potapov to a bronze medal at the 1972 Olympics in the Finn class, and to two World titles in the Tornado. As a coach, Chumakov was part of the official USSR delegation at the 1972 (Kiel) and 1980 Olympics (Tallinn). In 1981 Chumakov wrote the book Sailing School. At the beginning of the 1980s, Chumakov, while serving as a judge at the Baltic Regatta, suffered a head injury during an unsuccessful jump from a referee ship to the pier. This injury later led to his early retirement.

name: Elisabetta Pizio
special_notes: Wife of Ermanno Ioriatti Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short Track Speed Skating Championships (0–0–1 1987 Montréal bronze: 3000 m relay)

name: Joseph Harper
description: Joseph Harper competed at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics in Canadian singles flatwater racing. Harper made the US junior team in 1983 and competed internationally at the Junior World Championships before moving up to the senior ranks. He had competed in basketball and as a pole vaulter in high school, and later attended Long Beach State, where he earned a degree in criminal justice. After the 1996 Olympics, Harper used that degree to pursue a career in law enforcement. He worked as an undercover detective in the San Diego area, beginning in 1998. He led many projects helping to make the inner city areas safer and has been named Officer of the Year in his precinct.

name: Matthew Clempner
description: Matthew Clempner had the following finishes at major championships – 1988 European Championship: 130.0 kg. Freestyle (8th).

name: Hugh Foley
description: Hugh Foley began rowing for Loyola University in Los Angeles, but transferred to LaSalle, graduating from there in 1966 with a degree in accounting. Rowing for Vesper BC, Foley won six U.S. championships, either in the eights or fours with. He also won several international regattas in Britain, Europe, and Australia, and at the 1967 Pan-American Games was joined by his 1964 Olympic teammates, Bill Stowe and Bob Zimonyi, to take a gold medal in the fours with. Hugh Foley remained active in rowing when he coached crew at Boston University from 1970-78, and was involved in team selection and training for the 1972 Olympic boats, plus various international races in 1974 and 1976 Foley initially worked as a programmer/accountant but in 1978 he and his family moved to Montana where he worked for Plum Creek Lumber in Human Resources and Production Supervision and they enjoyed hiking, biking, camping, and fishing in and around Glacier National Park. In 1990 they moved to Eugene, Oregon where Foley became a licensed financial advisor with Ameriprise Financial.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1967 Winnipeg ROW gold: coxed fours)

name: Jacques Viaene
description: Jacques Viaene competed for the French national water polo team from 1948-55, winning a silver medal at the 1955 Mediterranean Games. He competed at the 1950 and 1954 European Championships and was capped 24 times. Viaene was assassinated on the Moutonniere Road, near Algiers, in 1962, possibly related to the Algerian War of Independence.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Murdered (†19 September 1962. Presumed killed after going missing while driving near Al-Jaza'ir (Algiers).) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Mediterranean Games (0–1–0 1955 Barcelona WAP silver)

name: Tom Holt
description: The son of a civil engineer based in Uganda, Tom Holt and his older brother John learned to swim in Lake Victoria. A younger brother, Mick, was born in Mombassa, Kenya, and when the family returned from Africa, and lived in Monmouth, Wales, the brothers regularly swam in the River Wye. When their father heard of the exploits of Paul Radmilovic, Weston-super-Mare’s best known Olympic swimmer and water polo player, he moved the family to Weston in 1937 where the three siblings swam at the local baths. That same year, at the Somerset Boy Scouts Meeting at the Whitestone Baths, Tom won the junior cup, aged 13, while John won the senior cup. The three brothers all played together in the Weston water polo team and all three served their country in World War II. Tom and John in the RAF, while Mick served in the Royal Navy Air Arm. After the War, Tom reached the final of the 440 yards freestyle at the 1946 ASA Championships at New Brighton, and the following year, finished second in the 440 to brother John at the Western Counties Championship. Tom had his best finish in the Nationals at Scarborough in 1948, when he finished second behind the defending champion Jack Hale, in the 440 free. The three Holt brothers were all selected for the 1948 Olympics, but Mick could not compete in the water polo competition because he could not get time away from work with the Royal Navy Air Arm. After the War, Tom emigrated to Australia, and served as a warrant officer in the Royal Australian Air Force from 1952-78.
special_notes: Brother of John Holt

name: Katrin Schröder
description: East German rower Katrin Schröder partnered Kerstin Spittler in the coxless pairs at the 1988 Seoul Olympics and finished fourth. She won gold medals with the eights at the Youth World Championships in 1984 and 1985. In 1988 and 1989, Schröder won the East German national eights title, and also the silver medal at the 1989 Worlds.

name: Fukuzo Ota
description: Tenyo Ota was one of Japan’s best known history painters in the style of the 15th and 16th century Tosa School. Also known as Fukuzo Ota, he attended the Tokyo School of Fine Arts becoming a student of Meiji painters Yamana Nukigi and Tomone Kobori. During this time he was drafted to the Japanese army and served in the occupied Korea, where he was also active in archeological excavations. Later he was invited to the Bunten exhibition. Many of his works have been collected by National Museum of Modern Art. The Japanese Classical Polo, originally from China, is called Dakyū, which is also the original title of the painting that Ota submitted in Berlin. The game, however, is also played on foot and contains elements of North American lacrosse.

name: Svetlana Kopchikova
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (3–0–0 1985 Kobe SWI gold: 200 m medley, 4×100 m freestyle relay, and 4×200 m freestyle relay)

name: John Marvin
description: While attending MIT John Marvin was the national intercollegiate champion in 1946. At the U.S. Olympic Trials 10 years later, he tied with George O’Day in the Finn class, but under a tie-breaking rule involving superior secondary placings, Marvin was declared the winner and gained the place on the Olympic team.

name: Norbert Klaar
description: Rapid-fire pistol sports shooter Norbert Klaar won the gold medal in the 25 metres event at the 1976 Montréal Olympics, just ahead his teammate Jürgen Wiefel. In 1977, Klaar won a team gold at the European Championships, and in 1981, a team silver at the Worlds. In 1979, he won his only East German individual title. Klaar was employed by the People’s Police during his active career, and later studied state science. He then worked with the Ministry of Internal Affairs. After re-unification. he became Regional Chief Coach of Brandenburg.

name: Henry Masquilier Thiriez
description: Henry Masquilier was married to Élise Marie Thiriez and sometimes added her maiden name to his name. Although nothing is known about his musical background, it has been confirmed that he conducted the cantata “Ludus for Patria” in 1900 on the occasion of the final of the Challenge international du Nord, an international football tournament that was held in Northern France until World War I. At the time, Masquilier was the president of the Sporting Club Tourquennois and director of general store in Tourcoing. The chorus of the cantata is conveyed as follows: “Honor to you intrepid athletes, girded with laurels, so worthily conquered! Let us sing the heroes of our feasts, and glory to our valiant friends! International Challenge of the North.” Obviously, neither the text nor the music came from Masquilier. A piano score of the “cantata for choir with four men’s voices accompanied by brass band or orchestra” that was published in 1899 says that the text was written by Jules Pierre Joseph Rosoor (14 April 1852–22 April 1923) and the music composed by Jehan Roland (probably from Switzerland). But it also bears a dedication to Monsieur Henry Masquilier Fils.

description: Aleksandrs Avdejevs had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 1st 1977 K4 10000 m (with Vladimir Morozov, Aleksandr Shaparenko, and the non-Olympian Sergey Nikolsky), 1st 1978 K4 10000 m (with Vladimir Morozov, Aleksandr Shaparenko, and the non-Olympian Sergey Nikolsky), 1st 1979 K4 10000 m (with Sergey Nagorny, Aleksandr Shaparenko, and the non-Olympian Sergey Nikolsky), 1st 1983 K4 10000 m (with the non-Olympians Nikolay Astapkovich, Nikolay Baranov, and Aleksandr Yermilov), 2nd 1977 K4 1000 m (with Vladimir Morozov, Aleksandr Shaparenko, and the non-Olympian Sergey Nikolsky), 3rd 1979 K4 1000 m (with Aleksandr Shaparenko and the non-Olympians Sergey Nikolsky and Jonas Zautra).

name: Otakar Vindyš
description: Otakar Vindyš, who sometimes played under the pseudonym “Mihály,” began playing bandy with ČLTK Praha in 1902. He joined SK Slavia Praha in 1907 and stayed with them his entire long career, retiring after the 1926-27 season. He played both right wing and defense and was known for his skating speed and his fast breaks. Vindyš was one the original “Seven Musketeers” who represented Bohemia at the 1911 European Championships, which they won. He also played at the Europeans in 1912-13 and 1921-23 and 1925, winning a silver in 1913 with Bohemia, golds in 1922 and 1925 and a bronze in 1923 with Czechoslovakia. He competed at the 1920 Olympics, winning a bronze medal in ice hockey. Vindyš was also considered a top tennis player and had a master’s degree in engineering. He was later inducted into the Czech Ice Hockey Hall of Fame.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (3–2–1 1911 Berlin gold; 1912 Praha annuled (gold); 1913 München silver; 1921 Stockholm silver; 1922 St. Moritz gold; 1923 Antwerpen bronze; 1925 Štrbské Pleso and Starý Smokovec gold) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (0–0–1 1920 Antwerpen (Olympics) bronze)

name: Alfred Krohn
description: German rower Alfred Krohn was eliminated in the coxed fours at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics. His boat from RC Sturmvogel Berlin won the German national title the same year. No more results could be identified for Krohn.

name: Rifaat El-Fanaguili
description: Rifaat El-Fanaguili had to work as a carpenter to help support his family during his youth, but he played football at every opportunity that he got. After experimenting with several clubs, he was recruited from the Suez Club to Al-Ahly during the 1953-1954 season. He remained with that team until his 1970 retirement, and over the course of his domestic career earned seven Egyptian Premier League titles (1954, 1956-1959, 1961, and 1962) and the Egypt Cup four times (1956, 1958, 1961, and 1966). He also played for the national team of Egypt (known politically as the United Arab Republic from 1958 through 1971, following its brief 1958-1961 union with Syria) and represented his nation at two editions of the Olympic football tournament. In 1960 the UAR was eliminated in the preliminary round, but in 1964 the team survived to the bronze medal match, where it was eliminated by Germany. He also appeared in the first four editions of the Africa Cup of Nations, winning in 1957 and 1959, placing second in 1962, and coming in third in 1963. He spent several seasons coaching with his hometown Damietta SC, but left sport completely due to his disagreements with its politics and later operated a car rental business. A street in Damietta was named in his honour after his death.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 1956 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign (2 App. - 2 goals - 180 min. played: ETH 4:1 (a), ETH 5:2 (h)) Listed in Olympians Who Participated in the 1960 Olympic Football Qualification Campaign ()

name: Igor Kashkarov
description: In addition to his Olympic medal, Kashkarov was Soviet Champion in 1955 and 1959, won silver at the 1961 Universiade and was fourth at the 1958 European Championships. Kashkarov later worked as an athletics coach. Personal Best: HJ – 2.12 (1959).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Universiade (0–1–0 1961 Sofia ATH silver: high jump)

name: Giustiniano Marucco
description: Giustiniano Marucco was born in the small town of Maggiora (in Novara province), and played for only two clubs: Novara Calcio from 1920-26 and 1928/29, and for Juventus FC in 1927/28, appearing in about 100 matches, scoring 30 goals. He also played in two matches at the 1920 Olympics. After the end of his playing career, Marucco was very engaged with work and was director of SAINA (Società Anonima Industria Nazionale Aiellesi) in Aielli, in southern Italy, until his tragic death in a car accident at only 43-years-old.

name: Abbas Zandi
description: Abbas Zandai wrestled freestyle for Iran at the 1948, 1952, and 1956 Olympics. He started competitive wrestling at age 14 with the Babr Tiger Club in Tehran. He joined the Iranian national team when he was 17 and won the Pahlevan of Iran title the next year. Zandi was World Champion in 1954 and won gold at the 1958 Asian Games.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 1958 Tokyo WRE gold: freestyle heavyweight +87 kg)

name: Jorge Contreras

name: Harold Wilson
description: Harold Wilson joined Hallamshire Harriers at an early age and, in 1906, competed in his first mile race, at Hillsborough Park, Sheffield. At Rotherham just one week later, he enjoyed his first victory over the distance. Hallamshire were the dominant team on the Northern cross-country circuit at that time, and won the Northern title six ears in succession 1907-12. Wilson was a member of the winning team in the first two of those years. He was one of the favourites for the 1908 Olympic 1500 metres title after setting a “world record” of 3:59.8 at the British Olympic trials. Wilson the won the AAA mile title in 4:20.2, which topped the world rankings for the year. Wilson could not quite repeat his earlier form in the Olympic 1500 metres final, however, and took the silver medal, two metres behind the American Mel Sheppard. In the 3-miles team event he finished fifth individually, and for a man who was running well beyond his usual distance, it was an excellent performance to beat all but John Eisele (USA) of the foreign entrants. Wilson went to live and work in the United States in 1909, but the following year turned professional and moved to South Africa to race with his good friend Reggie Walker. Wilson enjoyed limited success there, and in Canada. He returned to England briefly, before making South Africa his permanent home, where he died in 1932. Personal Bests: 1500 – 3:59.8 (1908); Mile – 4:20.2 (1908); 2 miles – 9:40.8 (1910); 3 miles – 14:57.0 (1908).

name: Harry Klugmann
description: Harry Klugmann was an eventer who won a bronze medal with the West German team at the 1972 München Olympics, placing ninth individuall. In 1971 he won his first individual West German title, followed by another one in 1979 and three silvers in 1977, 1978, and 1980. At the Europeans Klugmann claimed a team gold in 1975 and a team silver in 1977, and in 1978 he added a team silver medal at the World Championships. He was awarded the Silver Bay Leaf in 1972, the highest German sports award.

name: George Beattie
description: A prolific sport shooter, George Beattie competed in three editions of the Summer Olympics for Canada and won just as many medals. In 1908 he was the runner-up in the individual trap event, behind countryman Walter Ewing, and won a second silver medal in the team tournament alongside Ewing, Mylie Fletcher, David McMackon, George Vivian, and Arthur Westover. In 1920 he was fifth in the team event (but had the highest score among his countrymen) and failed to medal in the individual competition. Four years later he captured his third and final silver medal with the Canadian team (William Barnes, John Black, James Montgomery, Samuel Newton, and Samuel Vance) and placed sixth individually. This team also came in third at that year’s British Championships. Beattie also won the Brewers and Maltsters Trophy in 1910. He lived most of life in Hamilton, Ontario and worked as a Wentworth County game warden.

name: Harald Gimpel
description: Harald Gimpel was an East German whitewater canoeist who won the bronze medal in the K-1 at the 1972 München Olympics in a surprisingly well-executed second run. The canoe slalom events were held on the canoe slalom course of Augsburg for the first time at Olympic Games (and for the last time until 1992). He won two bronze medals at the 1975 World Championships in Skopje in the individual K-1 and with the K-1 team. Domestically, he claimed East German K-1 team national titles in 1971-74. Individually, he came in second in 1975 and 1978, and third in 1971, 1972, 1974, 1976 and 1977. He was later inducted into the German Canoe Slalom Hall of Fame.

name: Pierre Verdé-Delisle
description: Pierre Verdé-Delisle played only mixed doubles at the 1900 Olympics. He played Wimbledon in 1908, losing in the second round of singles after a bye in round one, and then making the third round of the All-England Plate, the consolation tournament for first and second round losers. He also played doubles, losing in round two after a first round bye. Verdé-Delisle was a medical doctor.

name: Hans Lampe
description: Hans Lampe, the brother of the more successful swimmer Werner Lampe and uncle of Werner’s son Oliver, participated in the 100 m butterfly at the 1972 München Olympics, but was eliminated in the heats. Two years earlier, he won the European title at Barcelona. In 1970 and 1972, he won the West German titles in this event. He later became a graduated school teacher in geography, mathematics and sports.

name: Harry Buck
description: A well known sprinter and footballer in the Liverpool area, Harry Buck played for Rossendale United and Tranmere Rovers before joining Everton on amateur forms in 1908. The son of a Liverpool publican, his father’s pub was less than two miles away from Everton’s Goodison Park ground. Whilst he was on the club’s books for several years, the speedy right-winger played just one League game for Everton, in the 1-0 home defeat by Bradford City in April 1909. During his time at Goodison, he won the annual Everton and Liverpool Footballers 100 Yards Handicap Cup at New Brighton in 1910 when, off scratch, he beat Liverpool’s Arthur Goddard into second place. A clerk with the Lancashire & Yorkshire Railway Company, his work eventually took him to London and he joined Clapton Orient in February 1914. After the War he played for Millwall before returning to Merseyside and re-joining Tranmere Rovers.

name: Fernando Bernini
description: Fernando Bernini was an Italian shooter who competed in the early post-World War II years and was a member of the Italian team that won the rapid-fire team gold medal at the 1947 World Championships in Stockholm, alongside Linari, Bertoni and Mazzavillani. He then competed in the London Olympics the following year. A multiple Italian champion, Bernini won the individual rapid-fire gold medal at the 1955 Mediterranean Games in Barcelona, and was awarded an Italian gold medal for athletic valor in 1965.

name: Joe Bosworth
description: Joe Bosworth was a right-handed pitcher who played for the USA at the 1964 Olympic demonstration baseball tournament. He was then signed to play with the Kansas City Athletics in their minor league program. Bosworth started in the minors in 1965 and played through 1969 but never made it to the Major Leagues. He made it to Triple-A in 1969 with the Iowa Oaks of the American Association but he retired from baseball after that season.
